types.name: StringIndex
types.docstring:
A `StringIndex` represents an unicode-aware position within a string.

 This type is intentionally opaque - it is recommended to use the 
 `str.index_at(offset_by: Int) -> StringIndex` method to construct a 
 `StringIndex`.

methods.name: op_equal
methods.docstring: automatically derived

methods.name: output
methods.docstring: automatically derived

types.name: StringView
types.docstring:
A `StringView` represents a view of a String that maintains proper Unicode
 character boundaries. It allows safe access to a substring while handling 
 multi-byte characters correctly.
 alert deprecated "use @string.View instead"

methods.name: iter
methods.docstring: Returns an iterator over the Unicode characters in the string view.

methods.name: length
methods.docstring:
Returns the number of Unicode characters in this view.
 
 Note this has O(n) complexity where n is the length of the code points in 
 the view.

methods.name: length_eq
methods.docstring:
Test if the length of the view is equal to the given length.
 
 This has O(n) complexity where n is the length in the parameter.

methods.name: length_ge
methods.docstring:
Test if the length of the view is greater than or equal to the given length.
 
 This has O(n) complexity where n is the length in the parameter.

methods.name: op_as_view
methods.docstring:
Creates a new `View` from an existing `View`.
 
 # Example
 
 ```
 let str = "Hello不不不"
 let view = str[1:7]
 let view2 = view[1:5]
 inspect!(view2, content=
   "llo不"
 )
 ```

methods.name: op_get
methods.docstring:
Return the character at the given index.
 
 The time complexity is O(n) where n is the given index, as it needs to scan
 through the UTF-16 code units to find the nth Unicode character.
 
 # Example
 
 ```
 let str = "Hello不不不"
 let view = str[1:6]
 inspect!(view[0], content="e")
 inspect!(view[4], content="不")
 ```

methods.name: rev_get
methods.docstring:
Returns the character at the given index from the end of the view.
 
 The time complexity is O(n) where n is the given index, as it needs to scan
 through the UTF-16 code units to find the nth Unicode character.
 
 # Example
 
 ```
 let str = "Hello不不不"
 let view = str[1:6]
 inspect!(view.rev_get(0), content="不")
 inspect!(view.rev_get(4), content="e")
 ```

methods.name: to_string
methods.docstring:
Returns a new String containing a copy of the characters in this view.
 
 # Examples
 
 ```
 let str = "Hello World"
 let view = str[0:5]  // "Hello"
 inspect!(view.to_string(), content="Hello")
 ```

typealias.name: View
typealias.docstring:
A `@string.View` represents a view of a String that maintains proper Unicode
 character boundaries. It allows safe access to a substring while handling 
 multi-byte characters correctly.

methods.name: compare
methods.docstring:
Compare two strings.
 String with longer length is bigger.
 strings of the same length are compared in lexicalgraphic order.

methods.name: concat
methods.docstring:
Concatenate strings.

 ```
 let s = @string.concat(["Hello", ", ", "world!"])
 assert_eq!(s, "Hello, world!")
 let s = @string.concat(["a", "b", "c"], separator=",")
 assert_eq!(s, "a,b,c")
 ```

methods.name: contains
methods.docstring: Returns true if this string contains given sub string.

methods.name: default
methods.docstring: The empty string

methods.name: ends_with
methods.docstring: Returns true if this string ends with a sub string.

methods.name: fold
methods.docstring:
Note: This method operates on Unicode characters, not Utf16 code units.
 As a result, the count of characters passed to the folding function may not be equal to the length of the string.
methods.signature: fn String::fold[A](self : String, init~ : A, f : (A, Char) -> A) -> A

methods.name: from_array
methods.docstring:
Convert char array to string.

 ```
 let s = @string.from_array(['H', 'e', 'l', 'l', 'o'])
 assert_eq!(s, "Hello")
 ```

 Do not convert large datas to `Array[Char]` and build a string with `String::from_array`.

 For efficiency considerations, it's recommended to use `Buffer` instead.

methods.name: from_iter
methods.docstring:
Convert char iterator to string,
 a simple wrapper for `from_array`.

methods.name: index_at
methods.docstring:
Returns a `StringIndex` representing the position after skipping `offset_by` 
 Unicode characters. If the string has `n` Unicode characters, the returned 
 index will be `Some` if `0 <= offset_by <= n`, otherwise `None`.

 # Examples
 
 ```
 let str = "不不不"
 let offset = str.index_at(1).unwrap()                // Skip 1 character
 inspect!(offset, content="StringIndex(2)")              // Points to second emoji
 
 let offset = str.index_at(start=offset, 1).unwrap()  // Skip 2 characters
 inspect!(offset, content="StringIndex(4)")              // Points to third emoji

 let offset = str.index_at(4)                            // Skip 4 characters
 inspect!(offset, content="None")                        // Beyond end of string
 ```

methods.name: index_at_rev
methods.docstring:
Returns a `StringIndex` representing the position before skipping `offset_by` 
 Unicode characters from the end of the string.
 
 # Example
 
 ```
 let str = "不不不"
 let offset = str.index_at_rev(0)
 inspect!(offset, content="Some(StringIndex(6))")
 let offset = str.index_at_rev(1).unwrap()
 inspect!(offset, content="StringIndex(4)")
 let offset = str.index_at_rev(2, end = offset)
 inspect!(offset, content="Some(StringIndex(0))")
 let offset = str.index_at_rev(4)
 inspect!(offset, content="None")
 ```

methods.name: index_of
methods.docstring: Returns the first index of the sub string.
methods.signature: fn String::index_of(self : String, str : String, from~ : Int = ..) -> Int

methods.name: is_blank
methods.docstring: Returns true if this string is blank.

methods.name: is_empty
methods.docstring: Returns true if this string is empty.

methods.name: iter
methods.docstring:
Returns an iterator over the Unicode characters in the string.

 Note: This iterator yields Unicode characters, not Utf16 code units.
 As a result, the count of characters returned by `iter().count()` may not be equal to the length of the string returned by `length()`.

 ```
 let s = "Hello, World!不";
 assert_eq!(s.iter().count(), 14); // Unicode characters
 assert_eq!(s.length(), 15); // Utf16 code units
 ```

methods.name: last_index_of
methods.docstring: Returns the last index of the sub string.
methods.signature: fn String::last_index_of(self : String, str : String, from~ : Int = ..) -> Int

methods.name: length_eq
methods.docstring:
Test if the length of the string is equal to the given length.

 This has O(n) complexity where n is the length in the parameter.

methods.name: length_ge
methods.docstring:
Test if the length of the string is greater than or equal to the given length.

 This has O(n) complexity where n is the length in the parameter.

methods.name: op_as_view
methods.docstring:
Creates a `View` into a `String`.
 
 # Example
 
 ```
 let str = "Hello不不不"
 let view = str[1:6]
 inspect!(view, content=
  "ello不"
)
 ```
methods.signature: fn String::op_as_view(self : String, start~ : Int = .., end? : Int) -> StringView

methods.name: pad_end
methods.docstring:
`pad_end` is a new String with `padding_char`s suffixed to `self` if `self.length() < total_width`. The length of the
 returned string is `total_width`.

 Example:

 ```
 assert_eq!("2".pad_end(3, 'x'), "2xx")
 ```
methods.signature: fn String::pad_end(self : String, total_width : Int, padding_char : Char) -> String

methods.name: pad_start
methods.docstring:
`pad_start` is a new string with `padding_char`s prefixed to `self` if `self.length() < total_width`. The length of the
 returned string is `total_width`.

 Example:

 ```
 assert_eq!("2".pad_start(3, '0'), "002")
 ```
methods.signature: fn String::pad_start(self : String, total_width : Int, padding_char : Char) -> String

methods.name: repeat
methods.docstring: Repeats the string `n` times.

methods.name: replace
methods.docstring: Replace the first old string in this string to new string.
methods.signature: fn String::replace(self : String, old~ : String, new~ : String) -> String

methods.name: replace_all
methods.docstring: Replace all old string in this string to new string.
methods.signature: fn String::replace_all(self : String, old~ : String, new~ : String) -> String

methods.name: rev
methods.docstring: Reverse string

methods.name: rev_fold
methods.signature: fn String::rev_fold[A](self : String, init~ : A, f : (A, Char) -> A) -> A

methods.name: rev_get
methods.docstring:
Returns the character at the given index from the end of the string.

 # Examples

 ```moonbit
 let s = "Hello不不不"
 inspect!(s.rev_get(0), content="不")
 inspect!(s.rev_get(4), content="l")
 ```

 # Panics

 @alert unsafe "Panics if the index is out of bounds."

methods.name: rev_iter
methods.docstring:
Returns an iterator that yields characters from the end to the start of the string. This function handles
 Unicode surrogate pairs correctly, ensuring that characters are not split across surrogate pairs.

 # Parameters

 - `self` : The input `String` to be iterated in reverse.

 # Returns

 - An `Iter[Char]` that yields characters from the end to the start of the string.

 # Behavior

 - The function iterates over the string in reverse order.
 - If a trailing surrogate is encountered, it checks for a preceding leading surrogate to form a complete Unicode code point.
 - Yields each character or combined code point to the iterator.
 - Stops iteration if the `yield_` function returns `IterEnd`.

 # Examples

 ```
 let input = "Hello, World!"
 let reversed = input.rev_iter().collect()
 assert_eq!(reversed, ['!', 'd', 'l', 'r', 'o', 'W', ' ', ',', 'o', 'l', 'l', 'e', 'H'])
 ```

methods.name: split
methods.docstring:
Splits the input `String` into an `Iter` of `String` using the specified `separator`.

 # Parameters

 - `self` : The input `String` to be split.
 - `separator` : The `String` used as the delimiter for splitting.

 # Returns

 - An `Iter` of `String` where each element is a substring of the original string, separated by the `separator`.

 # Behavior

 - If the `separator` is an empty string (`""`), the function returns an `Iter` where each element is a single character from the input string converted to a `String`.
 - If the `separator` is not empty, the function searches for occurrences of the `separator` in the input string and yields substrings between these occurrences.
 - If no more occurrences of the `separator` are found, the remaining part of the string is yielded as the last element of the `Iter`.

 # Examples

 ```
 let input = "a,b,c,d"
 let separator = ","
 let result = input.split(separator).collect()
 assert_eq!(result, ["a", "b", "c", "d"])
 ```

methods.name: starts_with
methods.docstring: Returns true if this string starts with a sub string.

methods.name: to_array
methods.docstring: Converts the String into an array of Chars.

methods.name: to_bytes
methods.docstring: `String` holds a sequence of UTF-16 code units encoded in little endian format

methods.name: to_lower
methods.docstring: Converts this string to lowercase.

methods.name: to_upper
methods.docstring: Converts this string to uppercase.

methods.name: trim
methods.docstring: Removes all leading and trailing chars contained in the given string.

methods.name: trim_end
methods.docstring: Removes all trailing chars contained in the given string.

methods.name: trim_left
methods.docstring:
@alert deprecated "Use `String::trim_start` instead"
 @coverage.skip

methods.name: trim_right
methods.docstring:
@alert deprecated "Use `String::trim_end` instead"
 @coverage.skip

methods.name: trim_space
methods.docstring: Removes all leading and trailing spaces.

methods.name: trim_start
methods.docstring: Removes all leading chars contained in the given string.
